title: 114_s686
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. LIMITATION ON CERTAIN ALIENS CLAIMING EARNED INCOME TAX CREDIT." is a concise summary of a specific section related to limitations on aliens claiming earned income tax credit. The text chunk discusses an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding the prohibition of retroactive credit for certain immigrants granted deferred action. The text chunk explains that married individuals who are eligible for a tax credit cannot claim it if their spouse is an alien granted deferred action. An alien granted deferred action cannot claim a tax credit if authorized to work in the US for the entire taxable year. Aliens granted deferred action are ineligible for tax credits if authorized to work in the US for the entire taxable year. Substantial policy changes issued after the enactment date are also included in the amendment to the Internal Revenue Code. Aliens granted deferred action are ineligible for tax credits if authorized to work in the US for the entire taxable year. The Commissioner of Social Security provides information to the Secretary of Treasury regarding aliens granted deferred action. The text chunk discusses the eligibility criteria for individuals granted deferred action, including having a social security number assigned by the Commissioner of Social Security. The Commissioner of Social Security requires specific information for individuals granted deferred action, including their name, social security number, date of issuance, and additional details as determined necessary. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide the Commissioner with any needed information to fulfill these requirements. The amendments made by this section, as required by the Commissioner, apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2014.
